content.webTitle: 'Thanks for watching': an emotional Barrie Cassidy hosts his last Insiders

fields.headline: 'Thanks for watching': an emotional Barrie Cassidy hosts his last Insiders
fields.bodyText: After 18 years, Barrie Cassidy’s final Insiders observation wasn’t about the institution he had overseen as a stoic guardian of transparency and purveyor of truth. It wasn’t even about the players who he had alternatively terrified and charmed for almost two decades from a Melbourne studio on Sunday mornings, while in the real world eggs cooked and coffee was brewed. It was about those who had always been at the heart of what he did and why. And it was those people who caused Cassidy’s famously craggy face to soften in an emotional tide. The audience. “The night after Bob Hawke died I went to the John Curtin hotel in Melbourne – you were there, Mike [Bowers] – for old time’s sake and I ran into a young bloke who said to me, ‘a few years ago I went on Tinder’. And I thought, oh, where is this going. “He said that he found a post from a young woman who said that she wanted to meet somebody who watched Insiders, preferably with a hangover. He got in touch, they watched Insiders and now they’re married. “How good is Insiders! “I say that for this point of view that I’ll be thanking all of those around me later on, but it’s the audience. “It’s you that I want to just talk to you very briefly this morning. I’ve been over the years pulled up in the street so many times. So many emails from people who essentially make the same point that they change their routine, they change the way that they manage their Sunday mornings around Insiders. “I just loved hearing that along the journey. “So, my final message is that I am moving on. But next week, and into the future, it will be the same team, it will be the same coach, just a different captain. “So stay loyal because the people around me deserve that. They really do … and for the final time, thanks for watching.” The man whose straight-forward interviewing style had trapped Australia’s best and brightest political minds – and many of those in between – into corners they had no idea they were sauntering into for the best part of two decades, often setting the political agenda for the week, was humbled by those he’d sacrificed all those Sundays for. Guardian Australia photographer-at-large and Insiders co-creator, Mike Bowers, who ambushed his friend and colleague on the couch for a surprise Talking Pictures segment paying tribute to Cassidy, said at the end of the day everything Cassidy had built was for those who watched. “It was very emotional but, as is Barrie’s attitude, he wanted to fit in as much as possible in day-to-day politics, which is what Barrie is like. He is always the most excited person in the room over any story, political or otherwise. There’s a lesson for young journalists there – no matter how big you get, never lose your excitement for a story,” Bowers said. The genesis of what would become Insiders was hatched in a Brussels bar in early 2001, where the name translated to “sudden death”, by Bowers, Cassidy, Heather Ewart and Gaven Morris, who came up with the “Insiders casual” dress code – jacket but no tie. The idea was always for a Sunday morning political show, which not only held those in power to account, but helped explain the inner workings of Australia’s parliament to those who made the ultimate decisions on who should lead – voters. “He got very emotional at the end, but it was always about the viewers and the people around him,” Bowers said. “That never changed.” Cassidy watched as Australia’s best political journalists paid tribute to a man they considered a first among equals, a friend and mentor, alongside politicians, past and present, including the former prime minister John Howard and the late Bob Hawke. “Barrie Cassidy is a cliff that speaks,” David Marr said. “The cliff opens, out comes a brutally simple question, and the cliff just goes back into shape again, while his victim has to find an answer.” The Sky News political editor, David Speers, has been confirmed as the new, permanent host of Insiders, but he won’t be taking up the role until early next year, when his current contract runs its course. In the meantime, for a period Cassidy declared be known as ‘waiting for David’, a series of ABC hosts will fill the chair.
